title: The Silk Road: Connecting the ancient world through trade - Shannon Harris Castelo

multiple-choice.question: What was the approximate length of the Silk Road?

options.label: A

options.label: C
options.text: It facilitated the spread of Buddhism

options.label: D
options.text: It led to the decline of the Silk Road

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: It had no impact on the spread of technologies

options.label: D
options.text: It led to the development of new technologies

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: It had no impact on the spread of ideas and cultures

options.label: D
options.text: It led to the decline of ideas and cultures

options.label: D
options.text: It led to the decline of globalization

title: How does your brain respond to pain? - Karen D. Davis

multiple-choice.question: What is pain?

options.label: A
options.text: A physical sensation of pressure or weight

options.label: B
options.text: An unpleasant sensory and emotional experience associated with actual or potential tissue damage

options.label: C
options.text: A chemical reaction in the body

options.label: D
options.text: A mental state of happiness or relaxation

multiple-choice.question: What is the function of nociceptors in the perception of pain?

options.label: A
options.text: To send signals to the brain to initiate a response

options.label: B
options.text: To deliver endorphins and enkephalins to regulate and reduce pain

options.label: C
options.text: To activate motor pathways to take action

options.label: D
options.text: To process pain information in the brain

multiple-choice.question: What is the salience network in the brain?

options.label: A
options.text: A network that decides what to pay attention to

options.label: B
options.text: A network that delivers endorphins and enkephalins to regulate and reduce pain

options.label: C
options.text: A network that activates motor pathways to take action

options.label: D
options.text: A network that processes pain information in the brain

multiple-choice.question: Why do some people experience greater pain than others?

options.label: B
options.text: Because of their sensitivity and efficacy of the brain's pain circuits

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of modulation networks in the brain?

options.label: A
options.text: To activate motor pathways to take action

options.label: B
options.text: To deliver endorphins and enkephalins to regulate and reduce pain

options.label: C
options.text: To process pain information in the brain

options.label: D
options.text: To decide what to pay attention to

multiple-choice.question: Why is it important to understand the brain's response to pain?

options.label: A
options.text: To develop new treatments for pain

options.label: B
options.text: To understand the causes of pain

options.label: C
options.text: To develop new medications for pain

multiple-choice.question: What is the goal of personalized medicine in treating pain?

options.label: B
options.text: To tailor treatments to individual patients

options.label: C
options.text: To understand the causes of pain

options.label: D
options.text: To develop new medications for pain

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) in treating pain?

options.label: A
options.text: To diagnose the cause of pain

options.label: B
options.text: To develop new treatments for pain

options.label: C
options.text: To tailor treatments to individual patients

options.label: D
options.text: To understand the brain's response to pain

multiple-choice.question: Why have traditional treatments for pain often failed to help some patients?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they were not tailored to individual patients

options.label: C
options.text: Because they were not developed to treat chronic pain

multiple-choice.question: What is the future of pain treatment?

options.label: B
options.text: Developing new treatments that directly stimulate or block certain pain-sensing attention or modulation networks

title: How languages evolve - Alex Gendler

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea behind the biblical story of the Tower of Babel?

options.label: A
options.text: All human languages came from a single common ancestor.

options.label: B
options.text: All of humanity once spoke a single language until they suddenly split into many groups unable to understand each other.

options.label: C
options.text: The story of the Tower of Babel is a myth with no historical basis.

options.label: D
options.text: The story of the Tower of Babel is a scientific theory about the origins of language.

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated number of languages existing today?
What is the process by which modern linguists try to map the history of languages?

options.label: A
options.text: By tracing multiple languages back as far as they can to their common ancestor.

options.label: B
options.text: By comparing grammar and syntax only.

options.label: C
options.text: By looking for regular patterns of sound changes in vocabulary.

options.label: D
options.text: By only looking at the sounds of words.

multiple-choice.question: What is a group of all languages related in this way called?
What is the main problem linguists face when constructing language family trees?

options.label: A
options.text: Deciding where the branches at the bottom should end.

options.label: B
options.text: Deciding where the branches at the top should start.

options.label: C
options.text: Deciding which languages are related and which are not.

options.label: D
options.text: Deciding which languages are dialects and which are languages.

multiple-choice.question: What is the problem with tracing languages back in time towards the top of the tree?

options.label: C
options.text: We have the same amount of evidence.

options.label: D
options.text: We have evidence from other sources.

multiple-choice.question: What is the current division of major language families based on?

options.label: A
options.text: Relationships that can be established with reasonable certainty.

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference between languages and dialects?

options.label: A
options.text: Languages are spoken by more people than dialects.

options.label: B
options.text: Languages are spoken by fewer people than dialects.

options.label: C
options.text: Languages and dialects are spoken by the same number of people.

options.label: D
options.text: The difference between languages and dialects is a matter of changing political and national considerations.

multiple-choice.question: What can linguistics reveal about ancient peoples?

options.label: B
options.text: Their social status and economic conditions.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the story of the Tower of Babel?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a myth with no historical basis.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a scientific theory about the origins of language.

options.label: C
options.text: It suggests that all human languages came from a single common ancestor.

options.label: D
options.text: It highlights the diversity of human languages.
